sim¶

The simulation class treats field indicies as follows

Both the electric and magnetic fields are initialized to the same length, meaning that they have a slight offset in starting and ending locations in the simulation. The E-field at each time is stored in a Numpy array with the following structure

The H-field and current arrays have corresponding structures. The variables \(A_1\), \(A_2\), \(\gamma\), and \(\beta\) are represented using the following two dimensional array

where \(m_0\) is the starting index of the material. Increments along the vertical axis represent increments in the oscillator index \(j\), and increments along the horizontal axis represent increments in space.

  • Discuss the choice of \(\frac{\Delta t}{\Delta z}\approx c\)
  • Discuss how to create a current object
class rcfdtd_sim.sim.Mat(dn, ilen, mat0, epsiloninf, mata1, mata2, matg, matb, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex64'>)[source]¶

The Mat class is used to represent a material present in a simulation

Parameters:
  • dn – The temporal step size
  • ilen – The number of temporal indicies in the simulation
  • mat0 – The starting index of the material
  • epsiloninf – \(\epsilon_\infty\) inside the material
  • mata1 – A matrix representing \(A_1\) where axis=0 represents the \(j\) th oscillator and axis=1 represents the \(i\) th spatial index
  • mata2 – A matrix representing \(A_2\) where axis=0 represents the \(j\) th oscillator and axis=1 represents the \(i\) th spatial index
  • matg – A matrix representing \(\gamma\) where axis=0 represents the \(j\) th oscillator and axis=1 represents the \(i\) th spatial index
  • matb – A matrix representing \(\beta\) where axis=0 represents the \(j\) th oscillator and axis=1 represents the \(i\) th spatial index
get_pos()[source]¶

Returns a Numpy array of value 0 outside of the material and 1 inside of the material.

Returns:A Numpy array of value 0 outside of the material and 1 inside of the material
class rcfdtd_sim.sim.Sim(i0, i1, di, n0, n1, dn, epsilon0, mu0, cfield, boundary, mat=[], nstore=0, storelocs=[], dtype=<class 'numpy.complex64'>)[source]¶

Represents a single simulation. Field is initialized to all zeros.

Parameters:
  • i0 – The spatial value at which the field starts
  • i1 – The spatial value at which the field ends
  • di – The spatial step size
  • n0 – The temporal value at which the field starts
  • n1 – The temporal value at which the field ends
  • dn – The temporal step size
  • epsilon0 – \(\epsilon_0\)
  • mu0 – \(\mu_0\)
  • cfield – The current field
  • boundary – The boundary type of the field, either ‘zero’, for fields bounded by zeros, ‘periodic’ for periodic boundary conditions, or ‘mirror’ for boundaries that reflect inner field values
  • mat – A Mat object or a list of Mat objects that represent the materials present in the simulation, defaults to none
  • dtype – The data type to store the field values in
  • nstore – The number of temporal steps to save, defaults to zero
  • storelocs – A list of locations to save field values of at each step in time
static calc_dims(n0, n1, dn, i0, i1, di)[source]¶

Calculates the dimensions of the simulation in cells.

Parameters:
  • i0 – The spatial value at which the field starts
  • i1 – The spatial value at which the field ends
  • di – The spatial step size
  • n0 – The temporal value at which the field starts
  • n1 – The temporal value at which the field ends
  • dn – The temporal step size
Returns:

A tuple (nlen, ilen) of the temporal and spatial dimensions
export_fields()[source]¶

Exports all stored field values (the number of which is determined by nstore at initialization) along with the spatial and temporal bounds of each field cell.

Returns:A tuple (n, i, e, h, er, hr) where n is a Numpy array containing the spatial bounds of each field cell, i is a Numpy array containing the temporal bounds of each field cell, e is a Numpy array containing the E-field (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is space), h is a Numpy array containing the H-field (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is space), er is a Numpy array containing the reference E-field (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is space), hr is a Numpy array containing the reference H-field (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is space)
export_locs()[source]¶

Exports the value of each field at a specific location(s) (specified with storelocs at initialization) at each point in time.

Returns:A tuple (n, ls, els, erls, hls, hrls) where n is a Numpy array containing the spatial bounds of each field cell, ls is the list storelocs (the same storelocs that is passed to the Sim class during instantiation), els is a Numpy array containing the E-field at storelocs at each point in time (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is the respective storeloc location), erls is a Numpy array containing the reference E-field at storelocs at each point in time (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is the respective storeloc location), hls is a Numpy array containing the H-field at storelocs at each point in time (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is the respective storeloc location), and hrls is a Numpy array containing the reference H-field at storelocs at each point in time (axis=0 is time and axis=1 is the respective storeloc location)
get_bound_res()[source]¶

Returns the boundaries and resolution of the simulation.

Returns:A tuple (n0, n1, dn, i0, i1, di)
get_dims()[source]¶

Returns the dimensions of the field in cells.

Returns:A tuple (nlen, ilen) containing the temporal and spatial dimensions in cells
simulate()[source]¶

Executes the simulation.
